perturbation.original_text: 1.1      "Licensed Technology" shall mean software licensed to LICENSEE by D2 as listed in Exhibit A.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1      "Licensed Technology" shall mean any software, hardware, or documentation provided to LICENSEE by D2, regardless of whether it is listed in Exhibit A.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition confines "Licensed Technology" to Exhibit A. The revised definition broadens it to include anything D2 provides, creating uncertainty about what is subject to the license terms.

perturbation.original_text: 12.5     Survival of Confidentiality Obligations. This Article 12 will survive the termination of this Agreement, for any item of Confidential Information, for five (5) years after the disclosure of such Confidential Information to the receiving party under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.5     Survival of Confidentiality Obligations. This Article 12 will survive the termination of this Agreement. However, the duration for which Confidential Information must be protected shall be determined at D2's sole discretion, with no fixed expiry date. In some cases, it may not apply at all, and D2's confidential information may need to be declassified and disclosed to third-parties.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause establishes a five-year confidentiality period post-termination. The modification introduces uncertainty by stating that the confidentiality duration is at D2's discretion and may not apply. This creates conflicting obligations regarding confidentiality.

perturbation.original_text: 15.2     Venue. The parties agree that any litigation arising out of this Agreement shall be brought in the state courts in Delaware.
perturbation.changed_text: 15.2     Venue. The parties agree that any litigation arising out of this Agreement may be brought in any jurisdiction that D2 determines to be most convenient for D2.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies Delaware as the venue for litigation. The modified clause gives D2 the right to choose any jurisdiction, contradicting the initial agreement and creating uncertainty for LICENSEE regarding where legal proceedings will occur.
